tweets.text:
OK 1 like = 1 hot take on religion. 

Are you readyyyyy folkss https://t.co/vD9fA8mKu0
1. Conversions and losses of faith not nearly as rational as people like to pretend they are, and this is not shameful.

Some background/context for this thread: 

I came from a "culturally Christian" household, went to a Christian k-12 school (loved), and was very involved in my church. 

I went to Liberty University at the wish of my v conservative parents for one semester (hated).

2. Christianity should spend time examining the fluctuations of understanding of various virtues via cultural contexts as a tool to understand church history. 

For example, I think we have little appreciation or framework for meekness at the moment. https://t.co/w9sAg39riH
3. My faith and science are compatible.

4. Christians should talk about sex and bodies a LOT more. 

(talk about them with: less shame, more empathy, more willingness to listen)
https://t.co/hqlk8aZZ6w

5. Historically, christianity has played a massive part in creating culture and furthering innovation- 

this is tragically untrue at this moment in history.

6. Governments are poorly suited to take care of many of the problems they have been left to fix

(Most human difficulties that should be dealt w. deep empathy fall into this category)

The church is an entity that (in its ideal form) should be radically devoted to these problems

7. Christians are not better than anyone else! 

This is a central premise of the religion, and yet Christians are abhorrently bad at acknowledging this.

8. The chi rho - ☧ (aka the symbol in my bio that people always ask about)

is a way of representing the Greek word for Christ, and was used to mark particularly great passages in the margins

- is all around great & we need a resurgence of its use.

https://t.co/5VQJLjv0g9 https://t.co/6p2r6dZ2tG

9. Modesty culture, in its current state, is deeply problematic. 

However, I believe in the value of modesty (in dress, and otherwise). 

These two beliefs can be held simultaneously.
(we're getting into the truly hot takes now folks)
10. Scripturally, modesty in appearance is largely advocated for on behalf of the person dressings experience - primarily, lack of vanity, perpetuation of humility.
https://t.co/Qq5yOr7Ry2

11. The church and church leadership need to re-examine their relationship with women. 

https://t.co/tEpBKIb7bw
12. The "old testament God" and "new testament God" are one in the same, and we should strive to hold their attributes equally at all times.

13. Happiness is overrated. Christianity is a beautiful framework for processing emotions. 

Given the joy of the gospel, we can deeply feel grief and happiness and still contextualize or even "normalize" for the constant quiet underlying joy we know.

14. Mental health issues aren't a sin and cannot be fixed through acts of faith. 

The church is partially guilty for the death and unfair suffering of many by pushing those unjustified statements  on them.

15. Forgiveness is taught poorly by many Christians. You can do real damage to yourself& the other party by forcing forgiveness before it is readily given. 

Healing & time separate from a hurtful party are both valid & very very necessary to some bigger instances of forgiveness.

16. Personal example here: 

Despite family being a deeply held value of the church: 
estrangement and delayed family forgiveness in the instance of abuse is absolutely okay.

17. Porn is bad for your brain. 

(not explicitly a religious take i guess, but often the discussion takes place in religious settings)

< also caveat for next section of takes on the more internal aspects of faith, and transformational christianity >

a bunch of these thoughts were stirred up in convo with @rSanti97 @eigenrobot @_TamaraWinter & @petergodofsky the other day, and are in part theirs!

@rSanti97 @eigenrobot @_TamaraWinter @petergodofsky 18. Christianity and the church are enormously powerful institutions and especially communities - 

because of the loneliness epidemic there's a recent movement to often look at the church as a really strong community, and not much more.

But - 

The transformative power of the church cannot exist when it is viewed as a community alone. 

You cannot reverse engineer what makes the church so powerful and pick and choose some of those aspects in isolation.

19. Aristotle and CS Lewis are right:

Going through the motions of prayer, devotion, worship, and communion with your church body, in an effort to grow faith that does not exist is a valid way to approach your faith

20. "When you are behaving as if you loved someone, you will presently come to love him.”

This extends to other areas of Christian practice:

Love is a choice -  you actively choose to love your spouse, children, friends, and enemies.

21. Shalom, or "complete reconciliation, a state of the fullest flourishing and restoration in every dimension - physical, emotional, social, and spiritual" -

https://t.co/Bd5xp6n83L

https://t.co/JAL5ey74vt https://t.co/ZDT047ALEe

- is commonly understood as the original state of the garden of eden, or God's perfect intention for us. 

We began with shalom, and the restoration of the earth will entail perfect shalom again. 

"Shalom" is an all around excellent salutation & we need a resurgence of its use.

22. In the beginning and the end there are full shalom, where everything as it is intended to be and harmony is upheld.

All christians are called to become sub-creators, restorers of shalom. 

https://t.co/Bd5xp6n83L

23. This means that every form of work** Christians take part in holds deep importance & weightiness.  

We can (and should) view our work as bringing God's kingdom, the fullness of shalom, to fruition.

** work = rearranging the raw materials of a particular domain to draw out its potential for the flourishing of everyone.

The implications of this are interesting and very important but also complicated, and difficult to explain - stick with me here.

24. ∴ , Work is deeply good, honorable, and necessary. 

"Whatever you do, work heartily, as for the Lord and not for men, knowing that from the Lord you will receive the inheritance as your reward."

25. Xpianity yet again gives us an eternal context for our work and day to day monotony.

Repetition, minute details, unfair treatment etc, are of little consequence when viewed in context of the rewards in heaven. 

https://t.co/UMavesRDS3

26.  ∴, anything from being a mother to being a trashman holds equal and arguably eternal importance. 

Work in this context provides glimpses of the kingdom of heaven, of shalom, of complete flourishing.

27. We live for the line and not the dot. 

https://t.co/2H8ScUtI5s

re: this stabilizing force again, the promises of the world pale in comparison to the joy of what is to come. 

the world is deeply broken, and something better was intended for us. 
https://t.co/UMavesRDS3

28. Exulting in monotony and repetition is virtuous. 

The Bible tells us often to be like the little children, this is a very good example. 
https://t.co/QPTLaUslLn

29. Christ's power is made perfect in our weakness

The Bible is full of God using the most incredibly broken people (adulterers, murders, the cowardly), to show his goodness to others.

This is a feature of Xpianity, not a bug! 
https://t.co/sUWBRJFp4w
Now for some ~literary analysis~ of christianity

30. The gospels of Matthew, Mark, Luke, & John (each books of the Bible) are ~fascinating~ bc they communicate the core tenants of the gospel (the "good news") in 4 very different ways. 

These books were written differently for 4 groups of people then & now in the world! https://t.co/cAjFc7qvTV

I could go into a LOT of detail about this, but: 

each book uses drastically different
- literary devices (styles, logical devices, visual imagery),
- examples from history and Jesus' life,
-  and even the authors themselves, 

to communicate effectively to difference audiences. https://t.co/Yom3GC3YVz

31. NIHIL SUB SOLE NOVUM 

There is nothing new under the sun (vulgate translation of Ecclesiastes 1:9 from Hebrew).

https://t.co/L1Tel6npSL
32. Latin is super cool
extremo incepimus, nunc huc sumus https://t.co/EkEkQxS1Wk

33. Luna delendi est

https://t.co/oKIDVBdA9Z

34. Moralistic therapeutic deism, a culturally prevalent ideology, consists of the following core beliefs: 

-A God exists who created and ordered the world and watches over human life on earth.
- God wants people to be good, nice, and fair to each other

- The central goal of life is to be happy and to feel good about oneself.
- God does not need to be particularly involved in one's life except when God is needed to resolve a problem
Good people go to heaven when they die.

- is _not_ Christianity.

This is a good summary

 (despite the tone they take about teenagers) https://t.co/nRofodDGlD
35. Following Christianity and its core tenants as described in scripture will always be radical and counter-cultural.
36. The chief end of man is to glorify God and enjoy him forever.

37. This quote is from a Catechism (which is a really neat concept), 

It's a doctrinal manuals – often in the form of questions followed by answers to be memorized – a format great for learning core doctrine. 

(man here is shortened from mankind)

https://t.co/AhoEbnQjNy https://t.co/L9Qn7zCum2

I remember running a long cross country workout up near my coach who was also our geometry and logic teacher, & asking him what he thought Christians main purpose should be in life if they had to choose one. 

He answered with this above section from the westminister catechism.

I argued with him and a friend for the next hour of the run, and the next few workouts, and he answered sometimes from his own experience and more often from response sections of the same catechism. 

They provide a logical framework for Christianity & the church to teach from.

38. Christian parents & leaders spending inordinate amounts of time telling young people to not have premarital sex often has the unfortunate external effect of implying that purity is their greatest concern for a relationship.

39.Xpian parents & leaders focusing their efforts on telling females to protect their purity furthers: 
-unhealthy relationship dynamics (intimacy should be an active discussion between the 2!)
- & can further rape culture(young girls thinking that they are the gatekeeper of sex)
40. Modern Xpian purity culture also has unfortunate effects on males.

40. Another weird & sad external effect of purity culture is the commonly implied assumption that if you stay "pure" until marriage, that's the single and only step necessary for a healthy sex life between you and your partner for the rest of time. (AHHHH!!!)
41. The Bible celebrates humans as sexual beings and recent American purity culture is a weird and ugly distortion of this truth.

42. The belief that sexual intimacy (& intimacy in general) is deeply meaningful and should be entered into carefully can coexist with the belief that humans are sexual beings and that that should be celebrated

Sidenote: 

I'm intentionally staying away from labeling v specific metrics/boundaries/rules because they're easy to argue over and don't get at the heart of the issue.

43. Christianity tells us that rules/law/instructions and us following them isn't about sticking to them by the letter, but about our hearts. 

Good works, right actions, come as a natural consequence for earnest hunger to become better.

44. The Pharisees and the many Biblical stories about them illustrate this concept.  

The were known  as self-righteous rule followers, obsessed with man-made rules (especially concerning purity) whereas Jesus in these stories is  more concerned with God's love. https://t.co/Jw7l4xkAPV

44. We are justified** by grace through faith. 

Not by works or following rules. This is radical.

(**God's righteous act of removing the guilt and penalty of sin while)

This differentiates Catholicism, Orthodoxy and Protestantism. It is also the fault line that separated Roman Catholicism from the Lutheran and Reformed traditions of Protestantism during the Reformation.
45. "The fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control; against such things there is no law."
46. Love should be the dominant attitude of Christians to those around them.

47. Love as defined Biblically is radical. 

"Love your neighbor as yourself." is often culturally antithetical.

48. People willfully misinterpret religions. 

Often, this has to do with emotional damage that the religions or something related has caused them.
(also y'all are allowed to argue with me in this thread, bc i know plenty of u disagree and i think we hold more common ground than you might think)
